title: Wave properties - speed in cans-and-string phone

content.question:
A toy consists of two metal cans connected by a long, thin, string that is stretched taut. When one person speaks into one can, the sound waves in the air cause the can to vibrate. The vibrations of the can then cause a wave that travels along the string. When the wave reaches the other end of the string, it causes the other can to vibrate, which creates a sound wave in the air that a second person can hear.
The toy is stretched between two students, Student <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and Student <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>. In case <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, Student <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> speaks into one can at a normal speaking volume. In case <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the students add additional tension to the string and Student <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> speaks into the can with a significantly quieter voice. Which of the following best indicates how the speeds of the waves on the string compare in the two cases and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: The speeds of the waves are the same in each case. The speed at which a wave propagates through a string is independent of the tension of the string.
The speeds of the waves are the same in each case. The speed at which a wave propagates through a string is a property of the string and does not change.
The speeds of the waves are different in the two cases. The speed at which a wave propagates through a string depends on the tension in the string.
The speeds of the waves are different in the two cases. The speed at which a wave propagates through a string depends on the energy carried by the wave.

content.answer: The speeds of the waves are different in the two cases. The speed at which a wave propagates through a string depends on the tension in the string.
